claim: For users who created more than 10 posts, the average up-vote count is roughly 95, and their average age is about 27 years.
extra_info: creating more than 10 post refers to Count (UserId) > 10; average of the up votes = Divide (Sum(UpVotes), Count (UserId)); average age = Divide (Sum(Age), Count(UserId))
reasoning: For users who created more than 10 posts (1165 users), the average UpVotes is approximately 182 (not ~95 as claimed), and the average age is either ~9.13 (SUM(Age)/COUNT of all qualifying users including NULLs) or ~34 (excluding NULLs), neither of which is ~27 as claimed. Both figures in the claim are contradicted by the data.

content.text: I'll verify this claim step by step. Let me start by exploring the database schema.

content.text:
Good. Now let me compute the averages as described in the hint. The hint says:
- "creating more than 10 posts" = COUNT(UserId) > 10 (counting posts per user)
- average up votes = SUM(UpVotes) / COUNT(UserId)
- average age = SUM(Age) / COUNT(UserId)

This means we first find users who have more than 10 posts, then compute the averages of UpVotes and Age across those users.

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "
SELECT 
  COUNT(*) as num_users,
  CAST(SUM(u.UpVotes) AS REAL) / COUNT(*) as avg_upvotes,
  CAST(SUM(u.Age) AS REAL) / COUNT(*) as avg_age
FROM users u
WHERE u.Id IN (
  SELECT OwnerUserId
  FROM posts
  GROUP BY OwnerUserId
  HAVING COUNT(OwnerUserId) > 10
);
"
input.description: Compute average upvotes and age for users with more than 10 posts

content.text: Hmm, the average age of ~9.13 seems off due to many NULL ages being counted in the denominator. Let me also check with the hint's exact formula which says `Divide(Sum(Age), Count(UserId))` - but this might mean counting only the users in this group. Let me also check what happens if we count only non-null ages, and also double-check the upvotes calculation.

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "
SELECT 
  COUNT(*) as num_users,
  AVG(u.UpVotes) as avg_upvotes,
  AVG(u.Age) as avg_age,
  SUM(u.UpVotes) as sum_upvotes,
  SUM(u.Age) as sum_age,
  COUNT(u.Age) as count_with_age
FROM users u
WHERE u.Id IN (
  SELECT OwnerUserId
  FROM posts
  GROUP BY OwnerUserId
  HAVING COUNT(OwnerUserId) > 10
);
"

content.text:
So with COUNT(*) = 1165 users:
- SUM(UpVotes) / COUNT = 212360 / 1165 ≈ 182.3
- SUM(Age) / COUNT = 10634 / 1165 ≈ 9.13
- AVG(Age) (excluding NULLs) = 10634 / 312 ≈ 34.08

The claim says average upvotes is roughly 95 and average age is about 27. Neither matches:
- Actual average upvotes: ~182 (not ~95)
- Actual average age: ~9.13 (using hint's formula with COUNT of all users) or ~34 (excluding NULLs) — neither is ~27.

Let me also verify using AVG which skips NULLs, just to be thorough, and also try an alternative interpretation where we count posts differently:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "
-- Alternative: maybe the hint means Count(UserId) in the posts table context
-- i.e., the count of posts, not users
SELECT 
  SUM(u.UpVotes) as sum_upvotes,
  SUM(u.Age) as sum_age,
  (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM posts p WHERE p.OwnerUserId IN (
    SELECT OwnerUserId FROM posts GROUP BY OwnerUserId HAVING COUNT(OwnerUserId) > 10
  )) as total_posts
FROM users u
WHERE u.Id IN (
  SELECT OwnerUserId FROM posts GROUP BY OwnerUserId HAVING COUNT(OwnerUserId) > 10
);
"
input.description: Check if dividing by total posts instead

content.text:
Dividing by total posts: 212360/52776 ≈ 4.02 for upvotes; 10634/52776 ≈ 0.2 for age. That doesn't match either.

The hint says `Divide(Sum(UpVotes), Count(UserId))` - the `Count(UserId)` likely refers to the count of distinct UserIds (i.e., 1165 users). No matter how I compute this, the numbers don't match the claim:

- Average upvotes: ~182 (claim says ~95) — **CONTRADICTED**
- Average age: ~9.13 or ~34 depending on NULL handling (claim says ~27) — **CONTRADICTED**

Both key figures in the claim are wrong.
